Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2008 07:17PM Sylvia42 wrote: Hi everyone, I just had a double stereotactic biopsy, on Oct. 9th, and wanted to describe the experience for women who are facing it.  My radiologist was great, as were the technicians--everyone was very focused on keeping me calm--rubbing my back during the procedure and generally being very positive.  I was extremely worried about it before I went in, and had asked for a Valium--they prescribed Xanax, which was very helpful.  They basically put your breast in a light vise-like contraption--not as painful as a mammogram, but similar, and then inject a lot of Lidocain.  This is painful the way a beesting hurts.  They then spend a lot of time fussing with the mammography equipment, and positioning the breast to get the right image.  It is stressful at this point becuase you cannot move a muscle (or risk disrupting the image).  Then they come at with you with the needle, which is admittedly big.  You feel pressure, and you hear a sort of "thunk" sound as it enters the breast, but you don't feel pain.  The idea of what is happening is worse than your perception of any pain of what is happening, if that makes sense.  I found myself, even with the Xanax, to be very tense and upset--though not really in pain.  You then hear the motor of the drill, which is extremely disconcerting--but again, not painful.  They take about 5-6 samples.  For me, the worst part was that I had to then have a second area done, and for this area they allowed a resident to come into the room.  I thought he would be only watching the procedure, which was bad enough (what kind of guy goes into this specialism of medicine?  it felt like some kind of weirdo had been admiited into what was up until then a woman-centered space), but it got worse when I realized that he was actually guiding the needle for part of the procedure.  My pain level increased a lot, and I was wincing from the idea that this guy, who I;d never met, was doing something to my body instead of my radiologist, whom I trusted.  I will be writing a letter to my breast care center about this aspect of the experience. Anyway, the second biopsy was completed in about 10 minutes, and then I was turned onto my back and taped up.  I told the people in the room about my discomfort with the "sneak attack" resident, and I would encourage other women to be more vocal in opposition to residents before they are brought into the room.  I got my results within 24 hours: all benign.  I am left wondering whether it was worth the stress, and whether the metal clips (made in Cincinnati, I asked for clarification on this) and the radiation (about 40 minutes' worth) might actually *give* me cancer, but at least for now I am cancer free.  I hope this helps, this is a wonderful site, sylvia
